articles.description:
NAIROBI, Oct 24 (IPS) - Almost all major river basins in Africa have become the epicentres for conflicts over the last 20 years, and agricultural yields on the continent could drop by up to 50 percent in the coming years owing to the drying up of 'traditional' water sources, thanks in part to effects climate change and degradation of the environment, the inaugural edition of the State of Africa's Environment Report 2023 released in Nairobi finds.

Read the full story, “Climate Change Turns African Rivers into Epicentres of Conflict”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Climate Change Turns African Rivers into Epicentres of Conflict

articles.description:
MEXICO CITY, Oct 24 (IPS) - The defense of the right to water led Gema Pacheco to become involved in environmental struggles in the southern Mexican state of Oaxaca, an area threatened by drought, land degradation, megaprojects, mining and deforestation.

Read the full story, “How to Defend the Environment and Survive in the Attempt, as a Woman in Mexico”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: How to Defend the Environment and Survive in the Attempt, as a Woman in Mexico

articles.description:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct 24 (IPS) - Brazil’s Supreme Court has delivered a long-awaited ruling upholding Brazilian Indigenous peoples’ claims to their traditional land. It did so by rejecting the ‘Temporal Framework’ principle, which only allowed for the demarcation and titling of lands physically occupied by the Indigenous groups who claimed them by 5 October 1988, when the current constitution was adopted. This excluded the numerous Indigenous communities who’d been violently expelled from their ancestral lands before then, including under military dictatorship between 1964 and 1985.

Read the full story, “Brazil: A Step Forward for Indigenous Peoples Rights”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Brazil: A Step Forward for Indigenous Peoples Rights

articles.description:
NEW YORK, Oct 24 (IPS) - The bloodletting in Israel-Palestine is nothing new, perhaps the ferocity and intensity has become much worse and more frenetic. Ever since the Zionist project to establish a Jewish nation took hold in 1948, and flourished thereafter, the local inhabitants, mostly Arab Muslims and Christians, were displaced in the power equation and became dispossessed in every sense of the word.

Read the full story, “The Road to Hell is Paved with Not-So-Good Intentions: Quo Vadis Israel-Palestine?”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Road to Hell is Paved with Not-So-Good Intentions: Quo Vadis Israel-Palestine?

articles.title: Migration Puts the Brakes on Venezuela's Vehicles

articles.description:
Recent developments in Kosovo highlight ongoing security challenges and political tensions in the region, highlighting the need for effective dialogue and cooperation, the UN envoy for the country said on Monday.

Read the full story, “Kosovo: Dialogue and building trust, key to defusing tensions”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Kosovo: Dialogue and building trust, key to defusing tensions

articles.description:
With 735 million people going hungry last year and three billion unable to afford a healthy diet, the world is “going backwards on our goal of zero hunger by 2030”, the UN chief told the Committee on World Food Security on Monday.

Read the full story, “Human right to food needs ‘massive investment’: Guterres”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Human right to food needs ‘massive investment’: Guterres

articles.description:
Femicide, which is the killing of women because of their gender, has reached “pandemic proportions” worldwide as countries fail in their duty to protect women, including trans women.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Femicide ‘pandemic’, war crimes appeal to Israeli lawyers, Syria child detainees”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Femicide ‘pandemic’, war crimes appeal to Israeli lawyers, Syria child detainees

articles.description:
The security situation continues to deteriorate in Haiti as gang violence grows, and elections are crucial for the sustainable rule of law, the UN Special Representative in the country, María Isabel Salvador, told the Security Council on Monday.

Read the full story, “Haiti: UN envoy upholds critical role of elections amid rising gang violence”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Haiti: UN envoy upholds critical role of elections amid rising gang violence

articles.description:
The number of people killed in Gaza has reached 5,087 according to latest reports from de facto authorities there, amid intensifying Israeli airstrikes in response to Hamas attacks, while humanitarians repeated urgent calls for a ceasefire and more aid convoys.

Read the full story, “Gaza death toll passes 5,000 with no ceasefire in sight”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza death toll passes 5,000 with no ceasefire in sight

articles.description:
NEW YORK, Oct 23 (IPS) - Amnesty International (AI), one of the leading human rights organizations, has accused Israeli forces of continuing “to intensify their cataclysmic assault on the occupied Gaza Strip.”

Read the full story, “Damning Evidence of War Crimes in Gaza”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Damning Evidence of War Crimes in Gaza

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Oct 23 (IPS) - The widespread use of American weapons by Israel, which has killed thousands of civilians in Gaza, has triggered accusations of war crimes against the United States.

But US has always escaped these charges in contemporary military conflicts –particularly in the killing fields of Afghanistan and Iraq --and also in the use of American weapons in Yemen where thousands have been killed.

Read the full story, “American Weapons Used in Gaza Trigger War Crime Accusations Against US”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: American Weapons Used in Gaza Trigger War Crime Accusations Against US

articles.description:
CAIRO & UNITED NATIONS, Oct 22 (IPS) - The ongoing violence in the Gaza Strip has resulted in a humanitarian crisis described as "catastrophic" – and even as aid arrived, strikes intensified.

Read the full story, “Gaza Humanitarian Crisis Worsens Even As First Aid Convoys Arrive”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza Humanitarian Crisis Worsens Even As First Aid Convoys Arrive

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
CIPHER BRIEF REPORTING – A second aid convoy arrived in Gaza as Israel continued striking targets in the region ahead of an expected ground operation [...] More 
The post Is Iran’s ‘Ring of Fire’ Strategy Heating Up? appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: Is Iran’s ‘Ring of Fire’ Strategy Heating Up?

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: A ceasefire in Gaza would only help Hamas, the White House said Tuesday, as Israel wages an air campaign against the militant group that carried out an unprecedented attack on the country earlier this month. Thousands of people have been killed on both sides since Hamas militants stormed across the border on October 7, executing civilians and seizing hostages, with Israel retaliating with relentless bombardment of the Gaza Strip.
articles.title: Gaza ceasefire 'only benefits Hamas': White House

articles.description: Michael Cohen, Donald Trump's former fixer, testified in court that he inflated the value of Trump's assets based on the number Trump told him to. Cohen, who had previously vowed to protect Trump, became a key witness against him in various legal proceedings. He is now involved in a lawsuit by the New York Attorney General, alleging that Trump and his company deceived banks and insurers by inflating his wealth. Trump denies the allegations and dismisses Cohen as a liar.
articles.title: Was told to boost asset values 'arbitrarily': Trump's ex-fixer

articles.description: The Biden administration is expressing concern that Israel may lack achievable military objectives and a workable plan for a ground invasion in Gaza. While the US still supports the idea of a ground invasion, senior administration officials have stressed the need for careful consideration and adherence to the law of war. The Pentagon has deployed Lt. Gen. James Glynn and other officers to assist Israel with the challenges of urban warfare, but they will not be on the ground if an incursion into Gaza occurs.
articles.title: Wary of Israel's action plan: US officials

articles.description: The Israeli military has shown nearly 44 minutes of raw footage to foreign reporters, depicting the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas assailants. The footage, collected from various sources including body cameras, dashcams, and social media accounts, shows bloodied corpses, charred bodies, and brutalized individuals. The military aims to create a collective memory and ensure that the world does not forget the atrocities committed, which they describe as both a war crime and a crime against humanity.
articles.title: 'Will not let world forget': Israel screens raw footage of Hamas brutal massacre

articles.description: Yocheved Lifshitz, an 85-year-old woman who was held hostage by Palestinian militants in Gaza, has described being beaten and taken through underground tunnels during her captivity. She is the first hostage to provide a public account of the conditions faced by the estimated 200 hostages held by Hamas and other armed groups in Gaza. Lifshitz was freed along with another woman, but their husbands remain in captivity. She recalled the horrors suffered by her neighbors during the attack on her town and stated that her kidnappers took care of her and provided medical treatment.
articles.title: 'Went through hell': Freed hostage, 85, recalls being in 'spider web' of tunnels

articles.description: Pakistan's former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, has been granted bail in corruption cases until October 26. Sharif, who was convicted on corruption charges in 2017, returned to Pakistan last week after four years in self-exile in London. The Islamabad High Court extended his protective bail after prosecutors from the anti-graft agency raised no objections. Sharif's convictions remain in force, but the court has barred authorities from arresting him until Tuesday, when he is due to appear in court. His legal team plans to pursue appeals against the convictions, with the aim of overturning them.
articles.title: Back in Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif gets bail in corruption cases

articles.description: Israeli security agencies have released video footage of the interrogations of seven Hamas terrorists who were captured after the attacks on October 7. In the videos, the terrorists confessed to receiving orders to commit acts of violence against Israeli civilians, including beheading and raping victims. The terrorists were apprehended during an assault on Kibbutz Alumim, where they killed 16 people from Thailand and Nepal and took eight others as hostages. The video aimed to counter doubts about the horrific acts committed by Hamas.
articles.title: IDF posts videos of Hamas terrorists detailing orders to kill, behead and rape

articles.description: Former school teacher Cassidy Kraus has been charged with engaging in sexual relations with three students between the ages of 13 and 14. She is facing charges of sharing explicit material with a minor, engaging in inappropriate conduct with a child, and third-degree sexual abuse. If found guilty, she could face a substantial prison sentence. Kraus is no longer employed at the school where the incidents allegedly took place and has already posted bail. Kraus posted a $10,000 bond the morning after her arrest and is scheduled to appear in court again on October 26.
articles.title: Female teacher, 24, accused of sexual misconduct with three of her students in US, including minors

articles.description: A Montana man pleaded not guilty to federal charges of threatening to assault and murder former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Richard Lee Rogers of Yellowstone County entered the plea during his initial appearance in federal court. Rogers is charged with threats to injure and murder a member of Congress, as well as making harassing telephone calls. The threats allegedly occurred in February and were intended as retaliation for McCarthy's actions as House speaker.
articles.title: Montana man pleads not guilty to charges that he threatened to kill former House Speaker McCarthy

articles.description: The UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, has warned that it may have to stop operations in the Gaza Strip unless urgent fuel deliveries are made. Aid agencies have expressed concern about the lack of fuel, which is necessary to power essential services such as hospitals. Six hospitals have already closed due to the fuel shortage, and the World Health Organization has stated that the limited supplies currently available will only last for a little over 24 hours.
articles.title: UN agency says to halt Gaza work unless fuel arrives

articles.description: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for the protection of civilians in the conflict between Israel and Hamas. He expressed concerns about violations of international humanitarian law. Guterres also emphasized the importance of respecting and protecting civilians, while also acknowledging the grievances of the Palestinian people. Israel's UN Ambassador criticized Guterres' remarks, accusing him of having a sympathetic view towards terrorism.
articles.title: UN chief pleads for Gazans' safety, cites humanitarian law violations

articles.author: Ishani Duttagupta
articles.description: The wait for permanent residency (green card) for Indians in the employment-based 2 and 3 categories in the US is getting longer. There are currently 1.1 million Indians in the queue for green cards, with most in the EB-2 and EB-3 categories. The US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) has announced that no more EB-2 or EB-3 I-485s from India will be accepted during fiscal year 2024 and beyond. This imbalance between supply and demand for green cards can only be addressed by Congress.
articles.title: Worrying news for Indians in line for green card

articles.description: A group of 20 Russian citizens, dressed in Ukrainian uniforms, are training at a shooting range outside Kyiv to join Ukraine's newly-formed Siberian Battalion. A Ukrainian military officer, who asked to remain anonymous, said most of the unit's 50 members came from Russia, travelling through third countries to reach Ukraine. The officer said most are from among the indigenous peoples of Siberia and recruits said they want to fight against what they said was Russian imperialism.
articles.title: Ukraine's Siberian Battalion recruits Russians to help fight Moscow

articles.description: Turkey's parliament speaker will send a bill approving Sweden's Nato membership bid to the foreign affairs commission. President Tayyip Erdogan submitted the bill on Monday, which must now be approved by the commission before being ratified by the general assembly. The commission chair will decide when to discuss the bill. Hungary will also make a decision regarding the ratification of Sweden's Nato bid. Finland's membership was sealed in April 2023.
articles.title: Turkish parliament commission set to study Swedish Nato bid

articles.description: Around 100 people were arrested in Egypt for participating in pro-Palestinian demonstrations last week, although some have since been released. The protests, approved by the state, were held in various locations, but some protesters walked to Tahrir Square, which was not authorized for the demonstration. The unauthorized protesters were quickly dispersed by security personnel. Unapproved public protests are banned in Egypt, and Tahrir Square is heavily monitored due to its symbolic significance.
articles.title: More than 100 detained in Egypt after pro-Palestinian protests: Lawyers

articles.description: House Republicans are holding a fresh round of voting through secret ballots to select a candidate for the position of House Speaker, following the removal of Kevin McCarthy. Majority Leader Steve Scalise and House Judiciary Chairman Jim Jordan initially withdrew their candidacies due to insufficient support. Seven candidates are now in contention, including Jack Bergman, Byron Donalds, Tom Emmer, Mike Johnson, Kevin Hern, Austin Scott, and Pete Sessions. The selection process involves multiple rounds of voting, with the candidate receiving the fewest votes being eliminated in each round.
articles.title: House Republicans to pick third Speaker nominee in as many weeks

articles.description: US News: WASHINGTON: Lawyers for Donald Trump are raising new challenges to the federal election subversion case against him, telling a judge that the indictme.
articles.title: Trump's lawyers file challenges to Washington election subversion case, calling it unconstitutional

articles.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited the People's Bank of China (PBOC) and the State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) in Beijing, according to sources. The purpose of the visit is unknown. China's economy grew faster than expected in the third quarter, but concerns remain about weakness in the private sector and the need for long-term reforms. The PBOC has been cautious about easing monetary policy due to fears of capital flight and depreciation pressure on the yuan.
articles.title: China's Xi Jinping makes first known visit to central bank: Sources

articles.description: A group of miners from an unregistered union are holding around 500 of their colleagues underground at a gold mine in South Africa over a union dispute. There have been scuffles and injuries, and conflicting statements about the events. The mine CEO believes the rival union members are holding the others hostage, while the rival union says there is a sit-in protest in support of the union. The National Union of Mineworkers is calling for law enforcement agencies to intervene.
articles.title: Miners from a rival union hold hundreds of colleagues underground at a gold mine in South Africa

articles.description: One person has been found dead and two others have been rescued after two freighters collided in the North Sea off the coast of Germany. The Verity, which sank, was on its way from Bremen to Immingham, while the Polesie was sailing from Hamburg to La Coruna. The vessels' cargoes are unknown. Four people from the Verity are still missing, while the Polesie had 22 people on board, none of whom were injured. Strong winds and waves were reported in the area.
articles.title: One dead, two rescued after North Sea ship collision: Authority

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: A Pakistani special court indicted on Monday jailed former PM Imran Khan and his incarcerated deputy, Shah Mehmood Qureshi, under the Official Secrets Act of 1923 in a cipher case linked to making public the contents of a classified diplomatic cable. ​The charge has added to legal hurdles that the PTI chief has been facing since his removal from office in 2022. Indictment for leaking confidential information carries a penalty of 14 years’ imprisonment and, in extreme cases, the death penalty, legal experts say.
articles.title: Imran indicted in cipher case, could face death penalty if convicted

articles.description: The explosion at a hospital in Gaza City was most likely caused by a missile fired from within Gaza, and not by a rocket from Israel, UK PM Rishi Sunak said on Monday. “The misreporting of this incident had a negative effect in the region, including on a vital US diplomatic effort and on tensions here at home.” The findings are in line with conclusion reached by the US, France and Canada. Hamas said  it cannot find the munition that hit the site and has declined to provide detail to support its count of 471 casualties.
articles.title: Now, Rishi Sunak also says Israel didn’t hit Gaza hospital

articles.description: A premature baby squirms inside a glass incubator in the neonatal ward of al-Aqsa Hospital in the central Gaza Strip. His life hinges on the constant flow of electricity, which is in danger of running out imminently unless the hospital can get more fuel for its generators. ​​Once the generators stop, hospital director Iyad Abu Zahar fears that the babies in the ward, unable to breathe on their own, will perish. Doctors treating premature babies across Gaza are grappling with similar fears. At least 130 premature babies are at “grave risk” across six neonatal units, aid workers said.
articles.title: ‘Genset fuel running out, 130 preterm babies at risk’

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan's Supreme Court has declared the trials of civilians in military courts to be null and void. The court ruled that citizens have the right to a fair trial under the constitution. A five-judge bench of the top court headed by Justice Ijazul Ahsan announced the verdict with a 4-1 majority. The court declared Section 2(1)(d) of the Army Act, which elaborates on persons subject to the act, to be in violation of the constitution and “of no legal effect”.
articles.title: Pakistan SC declares trial of civilians in military courts null and void

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte and emphasized the need for unity against Hamas, stating that "Hamas is ISIS." Rutte expressed his respect for Israel's efforts to defend against the attacks and restore safety. Netanyahu highlighted the severity of the situation, describing it as a battle of humanity against barbarism. Prior to the meeting, Netanyahu had conversations with the leaders of France, Spain, and the Netherlands, discussing Israel's determination to eliminate Hamas's military capabilities.
articles.title: 'We're in battle of civilisation against barbarism': Netanyahu to Dutch PM

articles.description: A fifth death has been confirmed in the UK following the severe weather brought by Storm Babet. The body of a man was found after he went missing in flood waters in Aberdeenshire, Scotland. This brings the total number of deaths in Scotland to three, with two additional deaths in England. Thousands of homes have been flooded and several hundred people are homeless. The storm has also caused damage in Germany, Norway, and Denmark. The UK is still on alert with more heavy rain expected.
articles.title: Fifth death confirmed in UK after Storm Babet

articles.description: The Taliban in Afghanistan are benefiting from international aid through fraudulent NGOs, according to a report by the US Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction. The Taliban has increased control over NGOs since seizing power in August 2021, using tactics such as extorting and infiltrating existing organizations. They have also barred Afghan women from NGO work and sought to push out foreign organizations from the education sector.
articles.title: Taliban exploiting international aid through 'fraudulent' NGOs, says US watchdog

articles.description: Iran hosted talks between the foreign ministers of Armenia and Azerbaijan, aiming to bring peace to the South Caucasus region. The talks took place against the backdrop of rising tensions in the Middle East. Iran's Foreign Minister emphasized the need for peace and cooperation, urging the removal of outside interference. The talks were attended by the foreign ministers of Russia and Turkey, and Iran expressed its readiness to assist in resolving the disputes between Armenia and Azerbaijan.
articles.title: Iran hosts Armenia-Azerbaijan talks, says they offer chance of South Caucasus peace

articles.description: The UK has announced an additional £20 million ($24 million) of aid to help civilians in Gaza affected by the conflict between Israel and Hamas. This brings the total amount pledged by Britain to Palestinian territories to £30 million. The UK had previously committed £27 million to Palestinians this year. UK leader Rishi Sunak also stated that the explosion at the Al-Ahli hospital in Gaza was likely caused by a missile fired from within Gaza, based on intelligence analysis.
articles.title: UK PM announces extra £20 million aid for civilians in Gaza

articles.description: Doctors in Gaza are in desperate need of fuel and basic medicines for their neonatal intensive care unit. The lack of electricity could result in the death of babies within minutes if their incubators lose power. The hospitals in Gaza are running out of fuel and are appealing to the world for help. The Israeli siege on Gaza has led to shortages of water, food, medicines, and fuel for the 2.3 million people living there. The situation is dire, with thousands of Palestinians killed and injured in Israeli air strikes.
articles.title: Gaza neonatal unit warns babies at risk 'within minutes' if power fails

articles.description: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has officially submitted Sweden's NATO membership application to parliament, bringing closer the end of a 17-month diplomatic standoff. Sweden dropped its policy of non-alignment last year after Russia's war on Ukraine, prompting its request for NATO membership. Hungary and Turkey are the only NATO members yet to ratify Sweden's membership. Erdogan agreed to put the ratification before the Turkish parliament at a NATO summit in July.
articles.title: Erdogan submits Sweden's NATO bid to Turkish parliament

articles.description: On Monday morning in downtown Boston, a tragic incident occurred as an individual fell from a high-rise office tower, resulting in their unfortunate demise, as confirmed by the police, reported NBC Boston. The authorities received a distress call at 7:54 a.m. reporting the fall from the building situated at 100 Summer Street. Regrettably, the worker who plummeted did not survive, as reported by law enforcement.
articles.title: Tragic fall claims worker's life in downtown Boston's high-rise

articles.description: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban criticized the leaders of the European Union (EU) during his campaign for the upcoming European Parliamentary elections. Orban referred to Brussels as a "bad contemporary parody" and expressed his belief that it can still be fixed. The EU has suspended funding to Hungary over concerns about the rule of law, complicating Orban's efforts to revive the country's economy. Despite his combative tone, Orban's top negotiator expressed optimism about resolving the funding dispute.
articles.title: Eyeing EU election, Orban calls Brussels a 'bad contemporary parody'

articles.description: Over 19,000 people have been displaced in Lebanon due to increased tensions between Israel and Hezbollah at the southern border, according to the International Organization for Migration. The organization expects these numbers to rise as tensions continue to escalate. The displacement adds additional stress to the already struggling resources of host communities in Lebanon, which is grappling with political paralysis, an economic crisis, and a fragile health system.
articles.title: More than 19,000 displaced in Lebanon amid tensions on Israeli border: UN agency

articles.description: A book that drew comparisons between an inept Chinese emperor and President Xi Jinping has been pulled from shelves in China. The book, titled "Chongzhen: The Diligent Emperor of a Fallen Dynasty was recalled on October 16, due to "printing problems", its publisher, Dook Media Group, said in an online notice. Chongzhen, whose reign ended with his suicide in 1644, was noted by historians for his diligence as much as his paranoia, including the constant questioning of his subjects' loyalty.
articles.title: Book critical of Ming emperor recalled after prompting online comparisons with Xi

articles.description: At least 20 people are feared dead and over 100 injured after two trains collided in Bangladesh.Officials fear that the toll could rise further with a significant number of people sustaining injuries.According to AFP, the crash took place in the eastern city of Bhairab when a freight train smashed into a passenger train travelling in the opposite direction.The collision caused two passenger carriages to derail, officials said. "We have recovered 15 bodies, many are injured," Sadiqur Rahman, a government administrator in Bhairab told AFP.
articles.title: At least 20 killed, scores injured as two trains collide in Bangladesh

articles.description: Israel continues to bombard Gaza with air strikes while soldiers fight Hamas militants on the ground. The conflict has also spread to southern Lebanon and the occupied West Bank. The United Nations warns that civilians in Gaza are running out of food, water, and shelter. Aid is slowly trickling into Gaza, but it is not enough to meet the needs of the population. Both Israel and Hamas reported overnight clashes in Gaza, with Israel conducting limited raids and airstrikes and gathering information on hostages held by Hamas. .
articles.title: Israel pounds Gaza as soldiers skirmish with Hamas

articles.description: Israel's military has conducted limited raids into the Gaza Strip, targeting sites where Palestinian militants are assembling. The raids, which involved tank and infantry forces, aimed to eliminate terrorist squads preparing for the next stage of the conflict. Israel's chief military spokesperson also stated that these interventions help gather intelligence on missing persons and hostages. The armed wing of Hamas claimed to have engaged with an infiltrating Israeli force, destroying two bulldozers and a tank. The Israeli military has not yet commented on these claims.
articles.title: Israel mounts limited Gaza ground raids, Hamas says it engages attackers

articles.description: Police in Cyprus on Monday arrested ten individuals suspected of running a crime gang trafficking migrants, as the island saw a fresh spike in arrivals over the weekend. Cyprus, which lies at the crossroads of three continents, has seen irregular migration rise since 2017. Cypriot officials have in recent days repeatedly expressed concern that the rapidly deteriorating security situation in the Middle East could lead to a surge in people fleeing the area.
articles.title: Cyprus busts refugee trafficking ring as more arrive from Mideast

articles.description: China's Middle East special envoy, Zhai Jun, has expressed concern about the situation in Gaza, stating that the risk of a large-scale ground conflict is growing. He highlighted the conflict spilling over into neighboring regions, including along the Israeli-Lebanese and Israeli-Syrian borders. Zhai called on the international community to be vigilant and take immediate action to avoid a serious humanitarian disaster. China is willing to promote dialogue, achieve a ceasefire, restore peace, and support a two-state solution.
articles.title: China says outlook worrisome as conflict spreads in Middle East: State media

articles.description: Two journalists in Iran have been sentenced to up to seven years in prison for collaborating with the US government and other charges. Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi were imprisoned for over a year following their coverage of Mahsa Amini's death in police custody. The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists has condemned the decision and called for their release. The journalists were charged with collaborating with the US government, colluding against national security, and propaganda against the system. Their detentions have sparked international criticism over the security force crackdown after Amini's death.
articles.title: Iran jails 2 journalists who covered hijab death row, for 'collaborating with US'

articles.description: Middle East News: JERUSALEM: Israel on Saturday described as "propaganda" a claim by Hamas that the militant group had wanted to release two more hostages on humanitari.
articles.title: Hamas says Israel rejected 2 more hostages, Tel Aviv says propaganda

articles.description: A teenage Iranian girl who fell into a coma earlier this month following an alleged encounter with officers over violating the country's hijab law is .
articles.title: Teen confronted on metro over hijab is likely 'brain dead'

articles.description: A second aid convoy entered the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing on Sunday, heading towards Gaza. Shortly after the convoy entered, a blast was heard and seven people were wounded. The Israeli military said one of its tanks accidentally fired and hit an Egyptian position near the border. The Egyptian military said the blast caused minor injuries and that an investigation is underway. The convoy carried medical and food supplies, and distribution of the supplies began on Sunday. However, aid officials are warning of a humanitarian disaster as supplies run low.
articles.title: Israel 'accidentally' fires at Egyptian post; 2nd aid convoy on way to Gaza

articles.description: Advocacy groups have reported a significant increase in antisemitic and Islamophobic incidents in the US and Europe since the recent Hamas attacks in Israel. The Anti-Defamation League recorded a 55% rise in antisemitic incidents in the US compared to the same period last year. There have also been spikes in anti-Israel rallies and antisemitic harassment on messaging apps. Similarly, the Council on American-Islamic Relations reported an increase in anti-Muslim incidents in the past week. In the UK, anti-Muslim attacks have increased sixfold, while France and Germany have also seen a rise in antisemitic incidents.
articles.title: Antisemitism, Islamophobia on rise in West

articles.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke with Qatar's PM about the issue of the hostages held by Hamas during the recent attack on Israel. Qatar played a significant role in delicate talks involving multiple countries to secure the release of the captives. When Hamas released two captives, the Raanan family, US officials thanked Qatar for their involvement. Families of the remaining hostages hope this is just the beginning. The hostages have likely been split into small groups, and it is unclear why the Raanans were released first, although their American nationality may have played a role.
articles.title: How diplomacy helped set free mom-daughter

articles.description: The Israeli military conducted an airstrike on a mosque in the occupied West Bank, resulting in the death of at least two people. The strike targeted an underground compound allegedly being used by Hamas and Islamic Jihad for organizing an imminent attack. The Palestinian foreign ministry condemned the airstrike as a "dangerous escalation" and accused Israel of using tactics from the Gaza Strip in the West Bank. Violence in the area has increased following recent attacks by Hamas.
articles.title: Israel strikes a 'terror compound' in West Bank

articles.description: US officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, have expressed concerns about the potential escalation of attacks on US troops in the West Asia region. They also mentioned the possibility of Iran trying to expand the Israel-Hamas conflict. The US has recently deployed additional military assets to the region, including a Thaad battery and extra Patriot battalions, to prevent the conflict from spreading. The US has already sent significant naval power and has troops stationed in Iraq and Syria.
articles.title: Pentagon sees threat to US troops in West Asia, beefs up military assets

articles.description: The Israel-Hamas conflict has raised concerns about a wider conflict in the region. Israel has continued to bombard Gaza, with the death toll rising. Clashes between Hezbollah and Israeli forces along the Lebanon border have also escalated. Israeli missiles have hit airports in Syria, where Iran has a military presence. Israel has warned of a potential ground offensive in Gaza, while also evacuating communities close to the Lebanon border. The situation remains tense, with fears of further escalation.
articles.title: Israel pummels Gaza amid fear of wider war

articles.description: Beijing and Manila traded blame on Sunday for two collisions between Chinese vessels and Philippine boats on a resupply mission to Filipino troops near Second Thomas Shoal in the Spratly Islands in the disputed South China Sea.
articles.title: China, Philippines row over collisions in disputed sea

articles.description: Rest of World News: Canada's opposition leader Pierre Poilievre has said that he would work to restore a "professional relationship" with India if his party came to offic.
articles.title: Canada opposition leader looks to 'restore' ties

articles.author: Aradhana Takhtani
articles.description: The chief minister of Penang, Malaysia, Chow Kon Yeow, attended a commemorative event for Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, marking the 80th anniversary of the provisional government and INA Raising Day. He expressed pride that Netaji had chosen Malaysia as a base to organize Indians against British colonial rule. In Bangkok, the Netaji Subhash Vision Thailand organization celebrated the anniversary with a 3-day "Netaji Pilgrimage" for academics and Indo-Thai citizens connected to Bose's historical visits to Thailand. The first-ever INA training camp was built in Chonburi, Thailand, where Indian migrant families supported Netaji's cause.
articles.title: South East Asia celebrates Netaji, reaffirms to honour legacy

articles.description: China is constructing the world's largest underwater microscope, the Tropical Deep-sea Neutrino Telescope (TRIDENT), to hunt for elusive neutrinos or "ghost particles" in the Western Pacific Ocean. Set to be completed in 2030, TRIDENT aims to capture neutrinos as they become detectable in the deep ocean depths, providing insights into their cosmic origins.
articles.title: China to build world's largest underwater 'ghost particle' detector

articles.description: Viet Thanh Nguyen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, had a reading event cancelled by a Jewish organization in New York City, a day after he signed an open letter condemning Israel's actions in Gaza. The organization, 92nd Street Y, postponed the event without giving a reason or offering an alternative date. The organization cited Nguyen's stance on Israel and the recent attack by Hamas as reasons for the postponement. Nguyen's representatives have not commented on the cancellation.
articles.title: Pulitzer winner's New York talk cancelled over Gaza stand

articles.description: Scientists at the University of Bristol have used supercomputer climate models to predict the formation of a future supercontinent called Pangea Ultima, which is expected to occur 250 million years from now. This continent will bring extreme temperatures, rendering it uninhabitable for mammals. The study attributes the dramatic increase in temperatures to heightened volcanism and the sun emitting more energy and heat as it ages. The research provides insights into how Earth's climate might change in the distant future due to natural processes. Despite concerns about contemporary climate change, the Earth is expected to remain habitable until the emergence of Pangea Ultima.
articles.title: Pangea Ultima: The uninhabitable supercontinent of Earth's distant future

articles.description: An international team of experts has analyzed ancient superdeep diamonds found in mines in Brazil and Western Africa to gain new insights into the early evolution of complex life on Earth. These rare diamonds, formed within the supercontinent Gondwana, provide information about the formation and movement of supercontinents. The research reveals that supercontinents played a role in concentrating deep oceanic plate subduction. The diamonds formed deep beneath Gondwana and were carried to the surface during volcanic eruptions.
articles.title: Geological time capsules: Diamonds tell the tale of Earth's ancient continents

articles.description: Amazon plans to test Agility's bipedal robot, Digit, in its nationwide fulfillment centers. Amazon Robotics has primarily focused on wheeled autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), but their interest in Digit shows their curiosity about walking robots and their potential. The integration of humanoid robots into Amazon's operations raises questions about scalability and adaptability. While this early-stage deal may not guarantee broader adoption, it highlights Amazon's interest in exploring robotics.
articles.title: Amazon testing humanoid robots in its warehouses

articles.description: Pope Francis and US president Joe Biden engaged in a 20-minute telephone conversation on Sunday, during which they discussed the Israel-Hamas conflict and various other ongoing wars, as reported by the Vatican. articles.description: Argentines will vote in a general election on Sunday amid the country's worst economic crisis in two decades. However, centrist Peronist Economy Minister Sergio Massa and conservative Patricia Bullrich are also strong contenders. The election outcome will have significant implications for Argentina's markets, trade relationships, and political trajectory.

articles.description: Amid an economic downturn and hyperinflation, many Pakistanis, particularly the younger generation, are seeking opportunities abroad for employment and scholarships. Over 450,000 Pakistanis are reported to have emigrated in the first three months of 2023. The British Council is also experiencing a surge in work and student visa applications. Some believe that this mass exodus can lead to increased international remittances benefiting Pakistan.
articles.title: Amid slump in economy, Pakistanis migrating abroad for better opportunities

articles.description: Yocheved Lifshitz, one of the Israeli hostages released by Hamas, said she "went through hell" and was beaten the day she was captured. But when asked why she shook the hand of a Hamas gunman when she was freed, she said they treated her with "softness and supplied all my needs." Charlie D'Agata has the latest on the ongoing war between Israel and Hamas.

articles.description: The U.S. has been quietly urging Israel to delay an expected ground assault in Gaza. A delay would hopefully allow for the release of more hostages and for more aid to get into the Gaza Strip, along with providing time for American troops to prepare for an expected uptick in attacks in the region. Nancy Cordes reports.

articles.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken tells "Face the Nation" that the U.S. is "concerned at the possibility of Iranian proxies, escalating their attacks against our own personnel, our own people. Not at all what we're looking for, not all we want, but we'll be prepared, if that's what they choose to do."

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.author: David Badash, The New Civil Rights Movement
articles.description:
A Rolling Stone report detailing Donald Trump's alleged plan for NATO if he wins the White House next year is making political experts greatly concerned.
"Trump and his team are actively planning to pull the United States out of NATO — or, barring that, kneecap the collective defense provisions at the heart of the alliance," writes Rolling Stone editor-in-chief Noah Shachtman.
"As this, and the damning tapes of Trump/Pratt conversation show, Donald Trump is the biggest internal threat to America's national security we have had since the Civil War," warns political scientist Norman Ornstein of The Atlantic, pointing to the Rolling Stone piece and the revelations about Trump's remarks to an Australian national in which he allegedly divulged U.S. nuclear submarine secrets.
"Donald Trump wante…
articles.title: Trump’s reported plan for NATO makes him ‘biggest internal threat to national security’

articles.author: David Edwards
articles.description:
During a press conference in Israel on Monday, Cohen noted that he was both an American and Israeli citizen. And he thanked Graham for supporting Israel. Graham is in Israel as part of a bipartisan US Senate delegation.

	"But it starts at home," Cohen said. "And I'd like to ask any Democrat senator here that would like to speak to Rashida Tlaib. She still has a tweet up condemning Israel for a hospital attack."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?

	"We are here together, not to talk about the problems at home, which are many," Graham shot back.


	"You're not going to screw this up!" Graham shouted.


	"Get this guy out of here!" Graham exclaimed.


	"I'm an American," Graham said, pounding on the podium.

READ MORE: Trump's Georgia racketeering trial could happen 'sooner than he expected': Ex-prosecutor

	"And I believe in free speech," Graham continued. "I don't believe what the squad has to say at all. But I came here with Democrats and Republicans to let everybody in the world know."


	Graham later apologized after his temper cooled.


Watch the video below from Newsmax.
articles.title: 'Get this guy out of here!' Lindsey Graham blows up at Newsmax reporter in Israel

articles.author: Brad Reed
articles.description:
Former President Donald Trump is pushing for a major American foreign policy change in his second administration that would likely upend decades of global national security infrastructure.
Sources tell Rolling Stone that Trump is planning to pull the United States entirely out of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance unless it caves to his demands that include one that would seem to undermine the entire purpose of the alliance.
In addition to his standard calls for other NATO countries to chip in more for their defense spending, Trump also reportedly wants to rip up the strategic doctrine that an attack on one NATO country represents an attack on all NATO countries.
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"When he was in office, Trump would repeatedly scoff at this collective-defense clause of the North Atlantic Treaty, known as Article 5," the publication writes. "One former senior administration official recalls to Rolling Stone a moment in the Oval Office in mid-2018 when the then-president started reading from a written list of smaller NATO countries, some of which he argued most Americans had never even heard of before."
Tearing up Article 5 would be a major boon for the likes of Russia, which attacked non-NATO member Ukraine in 2022 but notably has not attacked other NATO members on its border such as Estonia and Latvia.
Dr. Aaron Stein, a Black Sea Fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute, tells Rolling Stone that Trump's plan would be a "tremendously stupid endeavor" and added that "trading away allies based on ignorance, and Trump is ignorant about this issue, is just silly for broader U.S. national security."
articles.title: Trump plots 'tremendously stupid' NATO plan for his second term: report

With tensions mounting, Washington also announced Sunday it had ordered non-emergency staff to leave its embassy in Iraq.
"We are concerned at the possibility of Iranian proxies escalating their attacks against our own personnel, our own people," Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on CBS News. "We expect there is a likelihood of escalation."
"No one should take advantage of this moment to escalate to further attacks on Israel or, for that matter, attacks on us on our personnel."
Blinken said the United States, which has sent two carrier groups to the eastern Mediterranea…
articles.title: U.S. amps up military posture in Mideast, warns against 'escalation'

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The organiser of the Web Summit, one of the tech sector's leading events, announced his resignation Saturday following a backlash over his online posts following the Hamas attacks on Israel.
"Unfortunately, my personal comments have become a distraction from the event," Paddy Cosgrave of Ireland explained in a brief statement sent to AFP.
"I sincerely apologize again for any hurt I have caused," added the co-founder of the tech mega gathering created in 2009 in Dublin but held in Lisbon since 2016.
A spokesperson for the organization said: "Web Summit will appoint a new CEO as soon as possible, and Web Summit 2023 in Lisbon will go ahead as planned."
This year's edition from November 13 to 16, is set to bring together some 2,300 startups and more than 70,000 participants, say organizers.
Several companies, including tech giants Google and Meta, which is behind Facebook and Instagram, as well as event headliners have announced they are boycotting the gathering since Cosgrave's remarks.
He had written on X, formerly Twitter, that he was "shocked at the rhetoric and actions of so many Western leaders & governments" in support of Israel.
"War crimes are war crimes even when committed by allies, and should be called out for what they are," he wrote on October 13.
Since shock Hamas attacks on Israel on October 7, which left 1,400 dead, Israel has launched devastating air and ground bombardments of Gaza. The Hamas authorities say 4,385 people have died.
The boycott by Meta and Google followed other exits by companies and tech figures, including Intel, Siemens and US comedian Amy Poehler and X-Files actor Gillian Anderson.
articles.title: Web Summit chief resigns after Israel comments furor

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
A first anniversary in office is normally a moment for a leader to celebrate, but Britain's Rishi Sunak hits the milestone this week with a mountain to climb to retain power in a general election expected next year.

Two by-election losses to the main opposition Labour Party on Thursday underscored how Sunak, 43, has failed to revive the Conservatives' beleaguered fortunes during his first 12 months in charge.
"The more people see of Sunak, the less they like him in some ways," Tim Bale, author of a book about the right-wing Conservatives since Brexit, told AFP.
"He doesn't really project authority, he doesn't necessarily give the impression that he's in control of events.
"He looks, in part, as if he's sort of lurching from one policy initiative to another in a desperate attempt to curry …
articles.title: Sunak nears first anniversary as UK PM with little to celebrate

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Aboriginal Australian leaders ended their vow of silence on Monday to denounce millions of their compatriots for rejecting a landmark push for Indigenous rights, saying that the referendum result would be "etched into Australia's history forever".
Simmering racial divisions were exposed earlier this month when just over 60 percent of Australians voted against a referendum to acknowledge Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders within the 1901 constitution.
In the wake of the result, many Indigenous leaders embarked on a "week of silence", asking for time to grieve what they saw as a crushing rejection at the hands of Australia's white majority.
Some leaders ended that silence in a scathing open letter addressed to the government, criticizing the "appalling and mean-spirited" outlook of milli…
articles.title: Indigenous Australians denounce 'shameful' referendum result

articles.description:
A teenage Iranian girl, who fell into a coma earlier this month following an alleged encounter with officers over violating the country’s hijab law, is said to be "brain dead", Iranian state media reported on Sunday.
"Follow-ups on the latest health condition of Armita Geravand indicate that her health condition as brain dead seems certain despite the efforts of the medical staff," the Islamic Republic of Iran News Network said.
Iranian authorities have denied claims by rights groups that the 16-year-old was hurt after a confrontation on Oct. 1 with officers enforcing the mandatory Islamic dress code in the Tehran metro.

The report on Geravand could revive nationwide protests sparked by the death of 22-year-old Kurdish Iranian woman Mahsa Amini last year in the custody of morality police.
(Reuters)
articles.title: Iranian teenage girl ‘brain dead’ after alleged encounter with morality police over hijab

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Hurricane Norma slammed into Mexico's northwestern coast Saturday afternoon as a Category 1 storm, bringing dangerous rain and flooding, authorities said.
The storm came ashore about 25 kilometers (15 miles) northwest of the resort city of Cabo San Lucas on the Baja California coast, gradually weakening from a Category 3 as it approached land.
Norma was moving northeast at 9 kph, packing winds of up to 130 kph, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) reported at 2100 GMT. 
Norma was expected to bring rainfall of up to 45 centimeters (18 inches), producing "flash and urban flooding, along with mudslides in areas of higher terrain," the NHC said.
"Life-threatening surf and rip current conditions" would affect the coast of southwestern and west-central Mexico and Baja California Sur for the next couple of days.
Hotel employees in Cabo San Lucas urged guests to stay indoors until authorities give the all-clear, Gustavo Matamoros, a hotel worker, told AFP.
Local authorities say about 60,000 tourists are staying in the area, most of them international visitors.
Footage from Milenio TV showed flooded streets as Norma arrived. No casualties have been reported by authorities.
Norma should continue to weaken to a tropical storm as it moves toward the west coast of Mexico on Sunday.
Two people died last week when Hurricane Lidia struck the western states of Jalisco and Nayarit.
© Agence France-Presse
articles.title: Hurricane Norma makes landfall in Mexico as Category 1 storm

articles.author: Reuters UK
articles.description: By Leigh Thomas PARIS (Reuters) - Governments should open a new front in the international clampdown on tax evasion with a global minimum tax on billionaires, which could raise $250 billion annually, the EU Tax Observatory said on Monday. If levied, the sum would be equivalent to only 2% of the nearly $13 trillion in wealth owned by the 2,700 billionaires globally, the research group hosted at the Paris School of Economics said. Currently billionaires' effective personal tax is often far less than what other taxpayers of more modest means pay because they can park wealth in shell companies she...
articles.title: A global effort to stop billionaire tax evasion could earn $250 billion: study

articles.description: By Katya Golubkova TOKYO (Reuters) -Oil prices slid more than $1 on Monday as diplomatic efforts grew over the weekend to contain a conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, amid worries of a wider confrontation in the oil-rich region and pressure on supplies. Brent crude futures fell 67 cents to $91.49 a barrel, as of 0203 GMT, having lost $1.02 to $91.14 a barrel earlier in the session. U.S. West Texas Intermediate crude futures lost 72 cents to trade at $87.36 a barrel, after sliding $1.72 to $87.03 a barrel earlier on Monday. The contracts had risen more than 1% las...

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
Israel bombarded Gaza with air strikes early on Monday and its aircraft struck southern Lebanon overnight, as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convened a meeting of his top generals and his war cabinet to assess the escalating conflict. 
Israel's attacks concentrated on the Gaza Strip's centre and north, Palestinian media reported. A strike on a house near the Jabalia refugee camp, in northern Gaza, killed several Palestinians and wounded others, according to media reports.

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) — Argentina's general election vote was being counted on Sunday evening, with early signals suggesting the under-fire Peronist ruling coalition was performing better than expected, while all eyes remained on far-right libertarian radical Javier Milei. 
Argentines flocked to the polls on Sunday to vote in a tense national election where wild-haired outsider Milei has hogged the limelight amid the country's worst economic crisis in two decades and rising anger with the traditional elite.
articles.title: Argentina election vote count underway as run-off looks likely

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
A secret recording revealed by "60 Minutes Australia" exposed a conversation former President Donald Trump had with billionaire Anthony Pratt while he was in office, The New York Times reported. 
Pratt is the businessman whom the ex-president told classified secrets that are of the highest possible security level. Another thing Trump revealed is a detail from the call he had with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky in late 2019 that ultimately led to his first impeachment. 
Among the notes of the call, Trump told Zelensky that he would release the military equipment already allocated by Congress if and only if he did a "favor" for him. 


Declassified text of Trump's Ukraine call notes

            Photo: Scren capture
        



Trump bragged to Pratt: “That was nothing compared to what I usually do," admitting not only to the bribery but also that it's frequent behavior for him. 

"It is not clear whether Mr. Pratt shared these accounts with prosecutors or whether prosecutors are aware of the recordings," The Times reported. 
Another thing included in the report is that Trump asked his wife Melania to strut about Mar-a-Lago in a bikini. Another revelation is that behind closed doors Pratt was trashing Trump, even while he was still in office. 
Senate Republicans ultimately refused to hear beyond the opening statements of the Trump impeachment, voting to acquit him of the charges. 
Read the full report here.
articles.title: Trump told a friend the 'perfect' Ukraine call was 'nothing compared to what I usually do'

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
New court documents reviewed by the New York Times reveal Donald Trump's Australian pal, Anthony Pratt, told a lot of people about life at Mar-a-Lago post-presidency. Among the things he said, involved trashing Trump behind his back. 
Pratt, the Australian billionaire that Trump revealed classified information to, told around 45 people about the classified info as well as a number of things about his presidential pal.  
Not only did Trump tell his wife, Melania, to strut around the property in a bikini, but Pratt paid Trump tens of thousands of overages for ticket prices for events at the country club. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"Another witness told prosecutors about hearing uncorroborated reports that Mr. Pratt spent $1 million for tickets to a Mar-a-Lago New Year’…
articles.title: Secret recording reveals Australian billionaire pal was trashing Trump behind his back

"I have never resorted to a prohibited practice and never will," Gómez said in a statement on Instagram. He categorically rejects any form of doping. Gómez played for Sevilla last season, but had since signed for AC Monza in Italy. The player has called in a lawyer. He won the Wor...

articles.author: David Edwards
articles.description:
While appearing on ABC's This Week, host Jonathan Karl pressed Scott on his claim that U.S. "weakness" led to the terrorist attacks.

POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?be allowed to run for office?


	The candidate pointed to the Biden administration's decision to release $6 billion in Iranian funds.


	But Scott also acknowledged that Iran never received any of the money because the Biden administration froze it.


	"And to say that Joe Biden is complicit, which you also said, in the greatest, deadliest attack on the Jewish people since the Holocaust, I mean, that's beyond the pale, isn't it?" the ABC host asked.


	"There's no doubt that when you have President Biden negotiating with the Iranians for the release of hostages, I said this under President Obama as well, when we paid 400 million dollars for hostages, you were creating a market for American lives to be lost," Scott opined.


	Watch the video below from ABC or at the link. .
articles.title: 'Beyond the pale': ABC host hits Tim Scott for saying Biden has 'blood on his hands'

articles.description: A year has come to be a long and treacherous road in politics, as witnessed by the turbulence of late. But Rishi Sunak has survived his first as Prime Minister. Mr Sunak will have lasted more than seven times as long as Liz Truss’s fleeting tenure when he marks his first anniversary in No 10 on Wednesday. But No 10 is eager to dispel suggestions that there will be celebrations of any kind as he faces entrenched unease among Tories, a stuttering economy and crises abroad. Mr Sunak may have steadied the ship after his predecessor’s chaotic 49-day spell as prime minister, but he remains lagging a distant second behind Labour in the polls.

articles.description:
Republican Senator Tim Scott has stated United States President Joe Biden has “blood on his hands” after Hamas’ attack on Israel, says Curtin University Dean of Global Future Joe Siracusa. 

Mr Siracusa says the conflict between Palestine and Israel began “in earnest” after Biden’s administration “turned over $6 billion for the hostages to Iran”.

“Of course, Iran is behind this,” Mr Siracusa told Sky News Australia. 

“When the history books are written, those will be the opening.”

Officials say 4,741 Palestinians and 1,400 Israelis have been killed in the conflict as Israel’s military claims the number of people held hostage has risen to 212.
articles.title: Joe Biden ‘has blood on his hands’ with Israel-Hamas conflict

articles.description:
Agriculture Minister Murray Watt says every life taken in the conflict between Israel and Hamas is a “terrible thing”.

The Agriculture Minister says since the beginning, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the Labor government have “condemned Hamas’ attack on innocent Israeli lives”.

“We’ve said consistently that Israel has a right to defend itself,” Mr Watt told Sky News Australia. 

“But that doesn’t get away from the fact that every life in this conflict is worth something.

“We don’t want to see any more lives lost than absolutely needed.”

articles.description:
Nine Republican candidates have officially entered the race to become the next House speaker after the withdrawal of Jim Jordan. 

Several have signed a loyalty pledge to support the winner of the first vote, aiming to avoid the vote-counting confusion that followed Mr Jordan’s candidacy. 

This comes after earlier this month, former US House speaker Kevin McCarthy was ousted. 

“If we don’t have a speaker of the House, we can’t govern, and every day that goes by, we’re essentially shut down as a government,” Republican Representative Michael McCaul said. 

A secret vote with the GOP conference is scheduled for Tuesday as Republicans are encouraged to sign a unity pledge, promising to support whoever wins the vote.
articles.title: New Republican candidates enter US speaker race

articles.description:
Tyrrell's Wines Managing Director Bruce Tyrrell says the industry is going through a “pretty tough time at the moment” as Chinese sanctions on Australian wine are set to be removed.

The decision to remove the sanctions clears the way for the Prime Minister to visit Beijing next month.

Mr Tyrrell said Chinese wine consumption has dropped by about 60 per cent because “they can’t get the wine that they really like to drink”.

“As more and more Chinese people have travelled over the last 10 years, they’ve got to know Australia, they like Australia, they like Australians and got a great taste for Australian wine, so we really need to be back in that market,” he told Sky News Australia.

Mr Tyrrell hopes China’s economy will grow and Australian wine sales will grow with it.
articles.title: China set to remove tariffs on Australian wine

Bloomberg: Finland Says Hong Kong-Flagged Ship Anchor Breached Pipeline 

Finnish authorities raised a ship anchor on Tuesday from the seafloor in the area where an underwater gas pipeline was damaged earlier this month, saying a Hong Kong-flagged vessel appears to have caused the incident. 
The National Bureau of Investigation displayed pictures at a news conference of what it said was a 6-ton anchor that appears to be missing one of its arms, potentially belonging to the Hong Kong-flagged vessel “Newnew Polar Bear.” 
An investigation is proceeding into whether the damage was intentional, officials told reporters in Vantaa, just outside of Helsinki. 
Read more ....

Politico: Erdoğan, at last, sends Sweden’s NATO bid to Turkish parliament

 
Sweden welcomes the move, though the length of the Turkish approval process remains unclear. 
BRUSSELS — The Turkish government on Monday submitted Sweden's NATO accession bid to the country's parliament for ratification, ending a months-long guessing game over whether Ankara intended to postpone its approval process further.
"The Protocol on Sweden's NATO Accession was signed by President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan on October 23, 2023 and referred to the Grand National Assembly of Turkey," the presidency posted on social media platform X. 
Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson hailed the move. Welcome that President Erdoğan signed Sweden’s ratification protocol to NATO and submitted it to the Grand National Assembly of [Turkey]. Parliamentary procedures will now commence. We are looking forward to becoming a member of NATO," his office posted on the same platform.

 
Read more .... 
WNU Editor: Hungary is also a hold-out for Sweden to join NATO .... Hungary in the spotlight after Turkey presses on with Sweden’s bid to join NATO (The Hill/AP).

Turkey’s president submits protocol for Sweden’s admission into NATO to parliament for ratification -- AP

articles.description:
Moon Of Alabama: The Penny Drops - The World Is Multi-Polar 
In 2007, during his famous speech in Munich, the Russian President Vladimir Putin pointed to the inevitable rise of a multipolar world. 
He started out by defining the opposite state: 
   However, what is a unipolar world? However one might embellish this term, at the end of the day it refers to one type of situation, namely one centre of authority, one centre of force, one centre of decision-making. 
   It is world in which there is one master, one sovereign. And at the end of the day this is pernicious not only for all those within this system, but also for the sovereign itself because it destroys itself from within. 

Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: All that I can add to the above column is that I never expected this change to be happening as quickly as it is now.
articles.title: We Are Now Living In A Multi-Polar World

Axios: Top Biden official: Israel-Gaza war "could spiral" into bigger conflict 
In a 7,000-word tour of the globe's future, White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan writes that amid Middle East peril, America needs a long-term "sustained sense of confidence in our capacity to outcompete any country." 
Driving the news: "In the decade ahead, U.S. officials will spend more time than they did the past 30 years talking with countries that they disagree with, often on fundamental issues," Sullivan writes in the cover story of the forthcoming issue of Foreign Affairs, shared first with Axios. 
Why it matters: "The world is becoming more contested, and the United States cannot talk only with those who share its vision or values," Sullivan writes. 
 * "The coming era of competition will be unlike anything experienced before."

 
Read more ....

Washington Post: China’s top diplomat to visit D.C. amid tensions over South China Sea, Israel 
Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi will visit Washington this week, the State Department said Monday, the highest-level visit by a Chinese official since tensions spiked early this year after a Chinese spy balloon floated across American airspace. 
The three days of meetings, starting Thursday, are the latest sign that Beijing is laying the groundwork for a possible visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to a summit of Asia-Pacific leaders in San Francisco next month, which would be his first trip to the United States since 2017. 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: There is a summit of Asia-Pacific leaders in San Francisco next month, a summit that a Chinese leader would usually attend. But my gut is telling me that President Xi will not attend this summit even though the media is saying otherwise .... A top Chinese diplomat will visit Washington ahead of a possible meeting between Biden and Xi (AP). Current U.S. - China relations are in the toilet, and the leadership do not want to give any credit to the Biden administration, and they certainly do not want to meet President Biden. 
But in the event that President Xi does go to the US next month, I will see this as a signal that the Chinese are seeing the entire global order unraveling, and are making this trip as a last attempt to reverse this deterioration of global relations. 
Top Chinese Diplomat Visiting Washington Amid Tensions Between Beijing, DC

USA Today: Poll: Americans overwhelmingly back aid to Israel and Ukraine but split on US role in the world

 
The debate over military aid and global leadership has opened a generation gap and a partisan divide, a new USA TODAY/Suffolk poll finds. 
Most Americans support sending additional military aid to Israel and Ukraine, a new USA TODAY/Suffolk University Poll finds, but a divide is deepening between those who see U.S. global leadership as crucial and those who want to pull back from the world to focus on problems at home instead. 
The survey found double-digit support for aid to Israel in its battle against the terrorist group Hamas, 58%-35%, and majority support for sending more aid to Ukraine in its war with Russia, 51%-43%. 
Additional military aid to Taiwan, which faces a continuing threat from China, was backed by a smaller margin, 43%-39%. 
The poll of 1,000 registered voters, taken Oct. 17-20 by landline and cell phone, has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points. 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: This explains why politically the White House sees their policy towards Ukraine and Israel as a winning one in the 2024 election cycle.
articles.title: Poll: Americans Overwhelmingly Back Giving Aid To Israel And Ukraine

Top spokesperson laughs off media reports that Russian president is seriously ill. 
The Kremlin has brushed off claims that Russian President Vladimir Putin is ill, after speculative media reports that he’d suffered a cardiac arrest.

Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov also dismissed speculation that Putin has used body doubles to cover for him in public appearances. 
“Talk of Vladimir Putin’s health problems is another canard,” Peskov said, according to Russian state-owned news agency Ria.ru, adding that “everything is fine with him.”

AFP: Israel-Hamas war threatens world economy, bankers tell Saudi forum 
The war between Israel and Hamas could deal a heavy blow to the global economy, banking titans told a glitzy investment forum in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday. 
The dour mood from some of the gathering's most high-profile speakers underscored how the war threatens attempts by the world's biggest oil exporter to diversify its economy away from fossil fuels. 
Hamas militants stormed into Israel from the Gaza Strip on October 7 and killed at least 1,400 people, mostly civilians who were shot or burnt to death on the first day of the raid, according to Israeli officials.

Just four months ago, China’s defense minister, Gen. Li Shangfu, was at a forum for regional officials in Singapore, serving as the face of his country’s bold vision for reshaping Asia’s balance of power. 
He cast China as a force for stability and accused the United States of stirring trouble in the region, suggesting that its leaders should “mind your own business.” 
Now, General Li has been dismissed after nearly two months out of public view — the latest example of China’s capricious rules of power under the strongman leader Xi Jinping.

Reuters: Gaza authorities say 700 Palestinians killed in overnight strikes as Israel intensifies bombing campaign 
GAZA/JERUSALEM (Reuters) - More than 700 Palestinians were killed in overnight Israeli air strikes, Gaza's health ministry said on Tuesday, the highest 24-hour death toll since Israel began a bombing campaign to crush Hamas militants who stunned the country with a deadly Oct. 7 attack. 
Israel said it had killed dozens of Hamas fighters in the overnight strikes on the besieged enclave but said its war to destroy the Islamist group would take time. 
As aid agencies warned that a humanitarian catastrophe was unfolding in Gaza, French President Emmanuel Macron flew to Israel to offer it support.

 
Read more ....

 
Update #1: Israel's increased strikes across Gaza kill more than 700 people in the past day, Palestinians say (AP)

WNU Editor: Considering the mayhem and destruction that is now happening in the Gaza strip my gut is telling me that no one really knows how many have died since the start of this war, let alone in the past 24 hours. But there is one thing that I do know for sure if this becomes a long war. When this is all over the final death toll number will be in the tens of thousands.
articles.title: Gaza Authorities Say 700 Palestinians Have Been Killed In Overnight Israeli Airstrikes

Washington Post: U.S. readies plans for mass evacuations if Gaza war escalates 
The Biden administration is preparing for the possibility that hundreds of thousands of American citizens will require evacuation from the Middle East if the bloodshed in Gaza cannot be contained, according to four officials familiar with the U.S. government’s contingency planning. 
The specter of such an operation comes as Israeli forces, aided by U.S. weapons and military advisers, prepare for what is widely expected to be a perilous ground offensive against Hamas militants responsible for the stunning cross-border attack that has reignited hostilities. 
The officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity to detail internal deliberations, said Americans living in Israel and neighboring Lebanon are of particular concern, though they stressed that an evacuation of that magnitude is considered a worst-case scenario and that other outcomes are seen as more likely. 

 
Read more ....

 
Update #1: As Israel-Hamas war escalates, US readies plans for mass evacuations of Americans (First Post) 
 
Update #2: US prepares for potential mass evacuations of Americans from Middle East — WaPo (TASS)

Washington Post: Ukrainian spies with deep ties to CIA wage shadow war against Russia 

KYIV — The cluttered car carrying a mother and her 12-year-old daughter seemed barely worth the attention of Russian security officials as it approached a border checkpoint. 


But the least conspicuous piece of luggage — a crate for a cat — was part of an elaborate, lethal plot. Ukrainian operatives had installed a hidden compartment in the pet carrier, according to security officials with knowledge of the operation, and used it to conceal components of a bomb. 


Four weeks later, the device detonated just outside Moscow in an SUV being driven by the daughter of a Russian nationalist who had urged his country to “kill, kill, kill” Ukrainians, an explosion signaling that the heart of Russia would not be spared the carnage of war. 


Read more ....

WNU Editor: This story is being covered comprehensively in Russia .... CIA-backed Ukrainian spies behind Russian journalist’s murder – WaPo (RT).  A prediction. I do not know when or how the Kremlin is going to be respond, but there is going to be blowback against the US.
